title: #134 – James O’Keefe, M.D.: Preventing cardiovascular disease and the risk of too much exercise
content: James O’Keefe is a preventative cardiologist and bestselling author of The Forever Young Diet and Lifestyle. In this episode, James discusses cardiac physiology and what makes the human heart susceptible to disease. He provides evidence for what supports his approach to exercise–elucidating both positive and negative kinds of exercise for heart health. He also discusses the role of nutrition, specific nutrients, and pharmacological interventions to support heart and brain longevity. In this episode, Rhonda provides her latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. She also touches on cancer risk including the relationship between cancer and exercise as well as the link between alcohol consumption and cancer. Additionally, Rhonda explains her new focus on exercise and protein consumption as well as how her perspective has shifted as it pertains to fasting and time-restricted feeding. Connect With Peter on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook and YouTube Download Download Subscribe Subscribe Share Share § Show NotesJames’ background and why he favors a preventative approach to cardiology [3:15] How Peter and James met Peter first met James more than ten years ago at a conference James spoke at Peter was shocked to learn from James’ talk that the 20-23 hours per week of cycling he was doing may be harmful James’ background Based on his fascination with the heart, he knew as young as age 13 or 14 that he wanted to become a cardiologist He started out as an interventional cardiologist, which is a cardiologist who focuses on corrective procedures such as installing stents and pacemakers and replacing heart valves He trained at the Mayo Clinic  In 1988, he started working at the Mid America Heart Institute with Geoffrey Hartzler, who invented infarct angioplasty A year or two into his career, he realized that angioplasty was not the ideal way to treat cardiovascular disease, which led to his interest in a more preventative approach “Even though it’s the leading killer in America, [coronary disease] should be an entirely preventable, medically-managed disease. Unless you have an MI [heart attack], you don’t need to be going in having procedures, stents electively. We have the tools.”   Understanding atherosclerosis and the misconception that it’s a “plumbing problem” [10:15] Balloon angioplasty and stents Coronary arteries are narrow – the left coronary artery for example is less than a half centimeter or a third of an inch wide During angioplasty, a catheter with a deflated balloon is inserted into the narrowing artery and the balloon is inflated with saline to restore flow In some cases, a stent is left behind to preserve the opening In cases of asymptomatic blockage, there is no evidence of benefit for stents (and only some evidence of benefit in an acute MI situation) Yet, stents are used frequently —  partly because of the economic incentive to do the procedure But also because of this flawed paradigm: That this it’s a “plumbing” issue The flawed paradigm is this: That blocked arteries are simply a plumbing issue— The thinking is …“You have blockages in your arteries. Well, duh. You get rid of the clog. That’s simple.” But in reality, “As logical as that is, it doesn’t really turn out to be true.” ⇒ For more on the overuse of stents, see episode of The Drive with Ethan Weiss The zit analogy for explaining atherosclerosis/cardiovascular disease: Similar in concept to a pimple or pustule, atherosclerosis starts with accumulation of oxidized triglycerides and LDL cholesterol that attracts monocytes and macrophages The monocytes and macrophages promote inflammation and thin the overlying collagen layer, facilitating rupture and subsequent development of scar tissue In response to rupture, platelets and fibrinogen accumulate into a thrombus (blood clot) Calcification of the arterial tissue is part of the healing process Angioplasty is useful for opening a blocked artery during a heart attack, but causes further damage in the process This is the basis for why James believes a preventative approach (i.e., lifestyle change) is more appropriate for asymptomatic cases Context around what calcification and a calcium score really means: Peter’s “bars on the window” analogy: One of Peter’s patients had a calcium score of ~100, which put him at the 75th to 90th percentile of risk for his age In the three locations primarily affected, he had 30% to 50% blockage Peter points out that this blockage and calcification is like bars on a window – it does not indicate that a break-in is about to happen, but rather that it is a bad neighborhood and that a break-in likely occurred in the past “It’s telling us that now is the time to act and add other agents to our toolkit for how we’re going to prevent myocardial death.” Assessment of coronary arterial calcification James uses an inexpensive ($50 per test) and low-radiation CT scan called CardioScan to measure coronary arterial calcification He believes that for men over age 40 and women over age 60, CardioScan is the equivalent of the mammogram for the heart (i.e., everyone should have one) James has seen cases where coronary arterial calcification exceeds calcification of the spine! Predisposition to arterial calcification is partly genetic, but in James’ words is “a highly modifiable process” “We can’t make the acne scars go away. They’re there forever once you have those calcium deposits. But we can pretty much make the risk go away. That’s why prevention is just so effective and so instrumental.” Figure 1. Anatomy of the heart. Image credit: wikipedia.org   The danger in excessive exercise—a reverse J-shaped mortality curve [21:15] If exercise were a drug … It would be the best drug we have for preventing heart disease, dementia, osteoporosis, depression, diabetes, and obesity But like any drug, the dose must be appropriate For decrease of serious cardiovascular disease, benefit of exercise starts at just 15 minutes of brisk walking per day and increases with an increasing amount of exercise At the most extreme doses of exercise, however, some of the benefit is lost “If exercise were a drug, it would be the best drug we have for preventing heart disease . . .preventing dementia, preventing osteoporosis, depression, diabetes, obesity.” ⇒ Watch Peter swim the Catalina Channel The amazing pumping capacity of the heart The heart is only about the size of a fist, but continuously pumps about 5 liters of blood throughout the body per minute, amounting to three to four billion beats throughout a lifetime During intense activity, the hearts of some athletes pump as much as 30-35 liters of blood per minute!  Professional cyclists and cross country skiers get as high as 40 liters per minute In a well trained athlete, intense exercise will increase heart rate by about three-fold, say 45 to 170 bpm for example The volume of blood being pumped, however, increases by about six-fold (5 to 30+ liters per minute) Increased cardiac output, or the volume of blood pumped per beat, explains this discrepancy For cardiac output to increase, the internal volume of the heart must also increase. With extreme amounts of exercise, this stretching of the heart can be problematic Oxidative stress of exercise In addition, exercise creates oxidative stress. After about 45 to 50 minutes of high-intensity exercise, the body’s antioxidant capacity to resolve the oxidative stress is exhausted and endothelial function is negatively affected at this point  This coincides with increased blood levels of troponins and the N-terminal prohormone of brain natriuretic peptide (NT pro-BNP), which are both markers of heart damage Dial it back as you age Especially after age 40 or 45, really protracted exercise will cause those small little micro damage, like overstretching and tearing This happens because the high levels of catecholamines and free radicals that are now unbuffered “If you want to run a marathon, fine, run one or two. It’s like climbing Mount Everest, if you ever do that, do it once, but don’t do it three times a year. . . you’ve got to move on to healthier forms of exercise.” Longevity versus performance A Formula One car is fast and powerful – it will perform at peak levels, but is not going to last for 500,000 miles   In contrast, a car that can last 500,000 miles is going to be more like a Honda Accord that has been well maintained and never driven faster than 70 mph. In short, longevity and performance are different goals In regard to health, James notes that if you want to run a marathon or do something similar for the sake of accomplishment, that is fine, but it should not become a regular habit Peter notes how some of his patients find purpose and/or comradery in extreme exercise and it is sometimes a struggle for them to embrace the tradeoff It took Peter three years to embrace the tradeoff himself James experienced this tradeoff himself—He competed in triathlons up until his mid forties, when he started noticing concerns with his heart rhythm, including premature ventricular and atrial contractions and supraventricular tachycardia  Premature ventricular contractions can be caused by the high levels of catecholamines and oxidative stress produced during prolonged intense exercise, resulting in fibrosis and scar tissue that can disrupt heart rhythm and facilitate development of atrial fibrillation A Harvard study by one of the “godfathers of the exercise movement” showed that the people who exercised the most lost 38% of the longevity benefit compared to those who exercised more moderately Ken Cooper, one of the founding fathers of modern aerobics once said, “If you’re running more than 15 miles a week, you’re doing it for some other reason besides health.” Further demonstrating the concerns of excessive exercise, professional cyclists have been shown to be more likely to develop atrial fibrillation   The story of Micah True—a case study of excessive exercise [49:15] Micah True He was an ultra-distance runner and is the subject of the popular book, Born to Run He frequently ran 50-100 mile races in the desert heat At the age of 58, he died suddenly while running  An autopsy of his heart revealed scarring of the atria and ventricles, particularly the right ventricle and the interventricular septum Evidence supporting the reverse J-shaped curve Since it is not practical to do randomized controlled trials on longevity for humans, the supporting data is primarily epidemiological Experimental studies, however, have been done in dogs and mice, and they have shown excessive exercise to result in dilated heart chambers  James recently published a review paper describing 10 large epidemiological studies, and all but two showed a very distinct reverse J-shaped curve for exercise dose and mortality  Figure 2. The reverse J-shaped curve for exercise dose and all-cause mortality demonstrated in 7 of 9 epidemiological studies. Image credit: O’Keefe et al., 2020   The best kinds of exercise for longevity—The Copenhagen City Heart Study [53:00]  The Copenhagen City Heart Study Nearly 10,000 Danes were followed for more than 20 years This study is the equivalent of the Framingham study, but for exercise Participants were grouped based on type of physical activity, including running, cycling, swimming, “health club activities” (i.e., exercising at a gym), tennis, badminton, and soccer James was shocked by the results – tennis, badminton, and soccer were associated with the greatest longevity benefit, followed by running, cycling, calisthenics, and swimming  As demonstrated in a meta-analysis, research has shown that social relationships are as important for predicting longevity as other well-established factors such as smoking and exercise Based on this, James believes that the benefits of activities like tennis, badminton, and soccer are that they “combine two medicines instead of one” by combining exercise with social interaction A major limitation of the Copenhagen study (and any multivariate analysis) is that  1) A lot of variables can’t be teased out 2) You don’t have the ability to closely understand the intervention—in this case there is tremendous variation in how the activities are being carried out, particularly in the “health club activities” category “… if you’re training for longevity, yeah, take it down a couple of notches, but also make sure that you have some play in your life. We played as kids, we need to be playing as adults even more because it’s so important, not only for social bonding from stress relief or antidepressant.”   Being a more balanced athlete and finding the right exercise intensity [58:45] The “opportunity cost” of extreme exercise and the need for balance Peter uses lost time as an argument against excessive exercise For example, running 50 miles per week requires so much time that does not leave adequate times for other important types of exercise such as strength training It also leaves less time to spend with family Peter notes that “life is a pretty complicated sport and it requires strength, stability, aerobic fitness, and anaerobic fitness.” James recommends things that will keep resting heart rate low, but also some high-intensity interval training to maintain maximal capacity, “high volumes are really high intensity exercise is just not the ideal approach to fitness” “… after 30 or 45 minutes of aerobic exercise, if you want to do more circle back home and do some yoga, do some weights, these things that don’t necessarily tax your heart the same way that the other high intensity sports do.” Finding the right exercise intensity Peter describes the importance of zone 2 aerobic exercise, which is done at a relatively low intensity, but approximately the highest intensity prior to mitochondrial capacity being exceeded and lactate accumulation increasing Zone 2 exercise was discussed in great depth in podcast episode 85 with Iñigo San Millán Peter also notes that most people do not spend not enough time at this intensity and spend too much time at intensities between zone 2 and maximal intensity A rough ratio should be 80% zone 2 and 20% zone 5 (i.e., max capacity) He believes this middle area of intensity (zones 3-4) is the least important zone to be training within   Heart rate during exercise, resting heart rate, and other important metrics [1:04:00] James is often asked, “What should your heart rate be during exercise?” James actually recommends that people not pay much attention to heart rate during exercise Instead, the most important parameters about pulse are: Resting HR—We want to get that nice and low Heart rate variability— we want that to be more variable when you take slow deep breaths This is why meditation or yoga is a really good thing to add to somebody’s fitness regimen Figure 3. Heart rate variability (HRV). Image credit: ouraring.com This JAMA study looked at the benefits of low-intensity exercise (i.e., lower heart rate) It showed that simply walking 12,000 steps per day decreased mortality risk by about two thirds  Also supporting the idea of their being a point of diminishing returns for exercise dosage, the benefit of walking steadily increased up until 12,000 steps per day, where it plateaued  Figure 4. Association between steps per day and all-cause mortality. Image credit: Saint-Maurice et al., 2020 Interpreting resting heart rate What plays a role in resting HR? Peter has noticed variation in the resting heart rate of his patients and wonders to what extent genetics is a contributing factor At equivalent fitness levels, women tend to have higher fasting heart rates than men A lower resting heart rate is associated with increased longevity Later in life, sick sinus syndrome can lower heart rate Alcohol consumption, stress, and inadequate sleep can all increase resting heart rate As a marker of health status James notices that lifestyle factors like overtraining, poor sleep, a lot of travel, stress, and illness will typically increase his resting heart rate by 5 or more beats per minute In James’ practice, it is common for his patients to lower their resting heart rate by 5-10 beats per minute through lifestyle intervention Greater decreases require serious commitment to losing weight, exercising, and getting fit Drops in resting heart rate are often accompanied by decreases in abdominal fat, blood pressure, triglycerides, and hemoglobin A1c   Nutrition for cardiovascular health [1:09:45] Jame’s experience with traditional dietary recommendations When he was in medical school (1980s), low-fat diets like the Pritikin Diet were very popular This type of diet was a “disaster” for him: Triglycerides increased from 80 to 300 HDL-C decreased from 50 to 33 His athletic performance declined Overall, he was not feeling as well The Mediterranean diet James believes that a Meditteranean diet emphasizing fish and minimization of refined carbohydrates, combined with intermittent fasting, is the best dietary approach for cardiovascular health He recently published a review article on this topic He also believes that this dietary approach is also beneficial for preventing diabetes, dementia, obesity, and other common chronic diseases Peter and James agree that PREDIMED is a landmark nutrition study  This study was a randomized controlled trial that not only found a Mediterrenean diet to decrease risk of major cardiovascular events by about 30%, but showed decreased risk of diabetes, cognitive decline, and obesity in followup studies Interestingly, it was the added fat from olive oil and nuts that correlated best with the observed benefits James believes that a ketogenic diet should be structured more like a Mediterranean diet – it should emphasize fat from nuts, seeds, extra virgin olive oil, avocados, and oily fish over foods like cream cheese, butter, and red meat “… a diet that’s moderately high in fat, very low in refined carbohydrates, almost no added sugar, and minimal white refined grains but high in nuts and extra virgin olive oil and high in fish and seafood and high in vegetables and low in processed food, and drinking mostly water tea, coffee, fasting for at least 12 hours each 24-hour period of time and preferably moving to a 14- or 16-hour fast per day, we think this is arguably the healthiest cardiovascular diet.” Nuances of olive oil As suggested by Emilio Ros, the primary investigator for the PREDIMED study, the benefits of olive oil depend on it being extra virgin and having high polyphenol content   This type of olive oil should give a sensation at the back of the throat similar to black pepper One study found olive oil to have a negative effect on endothelial function, and according to James, this is because a high-polyphenol olive oil was not used Peter points out how consumers need to be aware – sometimes even products labeled as extra virgin olive oil are really nothing more than canola oil with some olive oil mixed in Saturated fat Peter notes that the epidemiology is confounded by people who consume more saturated fat typically also consuming unhealthy ingredients like refined carbohydrates James believes that a moderate amount of saturated fat is part of our evolutionary history, but that an excessive amount is not a good idea That said, he believes that sugar and other refined carbohydrates are a much greater concern “… that is again, our evolutionary history. We ate a lot of red meat and we ate saturated fats. The evil white crystal in the American diet is not salt. The worst is sugar. And sugar and refined carbohydrates are by far the absolute worst dietary villain. Saturated fat… A little bit of butter is not going to kill you.”   Important nutrients: Magnesium, potassium, calcium, sodium, and collagen [1:19:30] Magnesium and Potassium Peter is a strong proponent of magnesium: Peter likes it in the form of oxide combined with a slow mag Peter finds that supplementing magnesium on the order of two grams of magnesium a day almost always makes his patients feel better James points out that our evolutionary ancestors were getting about five times more magnesium and potassium (and fiber) Part of the reason for this is that they ate “nose to tail” Magnesium is an important cofactor for many reactions in the body Nuts are a good source of magnesium James also agrees with 2 g/d of magnesium as the right amount Calcium Eating “nose to tail” includes cooking bone, which provides calcium hydroxyapatite, which James says is a more appropriate form to eat Standard calcium supplements are in the form of calcium carbonate and calcium gluconate, which James says “… are rocks. We didn’t eat rocks. We ate bones.” James believes that 1 g/d of calcium is a good target Collagen Our ancestors consumed more collagen based on cooking bone and eating animal skin Since this is no longer common practice, James believes that collagen supplementation is valuable James points out that collagen is beneficial for hair, skin, nails, and bones;  And it is even beneficial for building and maintaining muscle mass b/c of the glycine and other amino acids Sodium James notes the need to be careful with sodium intake for people with heart failure and kidney disease Despite this, he rarely recommends that people limit sodium to less than 1,500 mg/d and believes that 2,000 – 3,000 mg/d is a better target When following a diet based on whole foods, James recommends salting to taste since these foods are low in sodium   SGLT2 inhibition for diabetes, cardio-protection, and general longevity [1:24:15] Background SGLT2 inhibitors are a class of drugs that blocks sodium glucose co-transporter 2 in the tubule of kidney cells This basically blocks reabsorption of glucose, resulting in increased excretion of glucose through the urine For this reason, SGLT2 inhibitors are used to treat diabetes Surprising benefits EMPA-REG, the first large clinical trial on an SGLT2 inhibitor, showed a decrease in heart failure hospitalizations and cardiovascular deaths in type 2 diabetics More trials have been done, confirming this benefit and also showing decreased risk of kidney failure, even in non-diabetics SGLT2 inhibitors for longevity Peter is interested in the potential of SGLT2 inhibition as an alternative to metformin for promoting longevity There is evidence of metformin impairing benefit from exercise, which does not appear to happen with SGLT2 inhibition James adds… James prescribes SGLT2 inhibitors to all of his type 2 diabetic patients But even for a non-diabetic person, you urinate out about a hundred grams of sugar a day “This basically is like pulling the plug and draining a substantial amount of sugar from your body every day.”  It raises ketones in your system—it taps into belly fat to get the fatty acids that then the liver turns into ketones “… we still don’t fully understand how it [SGLT2 inhibition] works, but it’s an important drug class that is going to only get bigger with respect to its impact on health and longevity.”  Why doesn’t it result in urinary tract infections? By increasing urinary excretion of glucose, SGLT2 inhibition could be expected to increase urinary tract infections, but this has not been the case James, however, has noticed increased frequency of yeast infections in women He recommends using a wet wipe after urination to help prevent this The role of insulin in the benefits of lowering glucose Peter points out that lowering glucose in type 2 diabetics only decreases cardiovascular mortality when the decrease in glucose is achieved without an increase in insulin James refers to the Drive podcast episode with Jason Fung while describing insulin as an obesity-promoting hormone that accelerates atherosclerosis when present at high levels For this reason, he considers insulin therapy to be a last resort for type 2 diabetics James co-authored a review paper describing evidence of insulin therapy increasing cardiovascular risk in type 2 diabetics He also notes that part of the reason why other drugs for diabetics have cardiovascular benefit is through decreasing insulin   GLP-1 agonists for weight loss and reducing cardiovascular risk [1:34:15] GLP-1 agonists GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) is a hormone that promotes insulin secretion and tends to decline in type 2 diabetics According to James, GLP-1 decreases glucagon production in the liver, thereby decreasing glucose production GLP-1 agonists lower fasting insulin and increase postprandial insulin James believes that GLP-1 agonists are great for weight loss and prescribes them accordingly Constipation and/or nausea may occur initially, but are likely to disappear over time In his patients, high-dose semaglutide results in weight loss of up to 10% of body weight In non-diabetics, he combines GLP-1 agonists with SGLT2 inhibitors Liraglutide is currently approved by the FDA for weight loss (for use once per day) and semaglutide is expected to be approved in the next year (for use once per week) Despite the lower frequency (once per week), semaglutide has been shown in multiple studies to be more effective for weight loss and reduction of hemoglobin A1c. Cardiovascular benefit is greater as well James notes that semaglutide is even an alternative to bariatric surgery James believes that GLP-1 agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors make a great combination because they promote weight loss and decrease cardiovascular risk through separate mechanisms (and are safe)   Statins—mechanism of action, safety, and useful alternatives [1:37:25] Peter notes that although statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis, their benefit is more likely a result of increasing the LCL receptor in the liver As an example of statins having pleiotropic benefit, James points out a study showing statin use to be associated with less severe COVID-19 infection This might be related to the anti-inflammatory effect statins are known to have Despite the large amount of evidence on efficacy of statins, Peter and James share their experience in having to defend against patients’ concerns about their use This is likely driven by misinformation on the internet While loss of coenzyme Q10 and associated muscle pain are legitimate concerns, they can be easily resolved through supplementation James mentions ezetimibe and PCSK9 inhibitors as alternatives to statins that do not interfere with cholesterol synthesis (as discussed in the latest Drive episode with Tom Dayspring) The association with decreased brain cholesterol with dementia is a good reason to considering alternatives to statin therapy (including a diet high in omega-3 fatty acids) For this reason, Peter measures desmosterol and lathosterol as markers of cholesterol synthesis in his patients, and is particularly cautious with patients who have one or two copies of APOE-4   A 40-year view on cardiovascular risk, and the possibility of reversing arterial calcification [1:45:45] 10-year cardiovascular risk If someone has a low 10-year risk calculation but has high ApoB, current recommendations are to do nothing beyond lifestyle modifications Based on the work of Allan Sniderman, Peter thinks it is more important to look at 30- or 40- year risk James notes that ezetimibe and PCSK9 inhibitors are actually preferable to statins in this context because statins can accelerate coronary artery calcification Peter personally takes a low dose pravastatin plus PCSK9 inhibitor, but is considering doing the experiment of switching to from pravastatin over to Zetia to see what changes Regression of coronary artery calcification Peter notes his calcium score of 6 at age 36 Peter suggests it was most likely attributable to a poor diet James thinks that the high volume of high intensity exercise also played a role Peter has since decreased his calcium score to 0 James says you virtually never see scores go down—he has read about 150,000 calcium scores and considers this rare – calcium score usually increases by 25-30% or more per year In one of James’ patients, however, he saw a calcium score over 1,000 drop by 200-300 after switching from statins to ezetimibe plus a PCSK9 inhibitor A recent study showed that using a PCSK9 inhibitor with a statin results in less coronary artery calcification than a statin alone Peter and James agree that re-testing calcium score is generally not necessary Although it may serve as motivation for patients who are not following recommendations, it can be discouraging for patients who are doing everything right “…we can prevent cardiovascular events with all these strategies we’re talking about, despite the coronary calcium.”   Evidence for high dose EPA and DHA for the reduction of cardiovascular disease risk [1:53:30] Background on omega-3 fatty acids Similar to other nutrients, James notes that we’re eating less omega-3 fatty acids than our evolutionary ancestors, maybe by an order of magnitude Some people believe that access to shellfish and seafood corresponded with human brain expansion 300,000-400,000 years ago About twenty percent of the brain’s dry weight is made of omega-3 fatty acids, particularly docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) from neuron membranes. Evidence supporting a decrease in cardiovascular risk from omega-3s The REDUCE-IT trial showed 4 g/d of a purified form of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) to decrease cardiovascular deaths and events in people with cardiovascular disease, diabetes, or risk factors including high triglycerides by 20% Another recent trial, the EVAPORATE study, showed 4 g/d of the same purified form of EPA to decrease coronary plaque by 17% The STRENGTH trial, however, looked at the effects of 4 g/d of a fish oil derivative including EPA+DHA on cardiovascular outcomes and was terminated early due to expected lack of effect A recent meta-analysis of 40 studies found EPA+DHA to decrease cardiovascular death and events Risk of fatal myocardial infarction was decreased by 35% Overall risk decreased by 5.8% for each additional gram per day of EPA+DHA (max dose evaluated was less than 6 g) James believes that dosage is important – 2 to 4 g/d produces impressive results while most studies that fail to find benefit have used lower doses Although it is not clearly known if EPA is better alone or in combination with DHA, James believes it is logical to include DHA based on its role in the brain and that we
